Comment: I know this comment is facetious, but the guy you’re replying to isn’t wrong.   I’m in Michigan and I’m homeless. The shelters near me suck. Multiple hour long lines to get in the building. Hour long line for breakfast or dinner (fair enough here, if you need free food waiting is an acceptable price), get kicked out in the morning and can’t reenter until late afternoon, they check your bags at night (and the room they’re stored in has been robbed by other homeless people breaking in and by employees), you get your bags checked, a full body pat down, blankets thrown away, vapes/cigarettes/lighter confiscated, subjected to xray machines, can’t bring in liquids or outside foods at all.   Maybe that all seems easy, but when you’re homeless a lot of these things feel like your lifeline.   I was outside in a sleeping bag over the winter through the weeks when it got to -6F/-15C covering and sealing myself close to the ground with a large quilt because it was genuinely easier than dealing with the shelter and being unable to have blankets to warm myself up with during the day or being sent outside in the morning when it was still freezing. With windchill it sometimes got to -20F feels like.   And that’s only speaking on the institutional part of things. I haven’t begun with dealing with some of the workers who treat you like abject scum or some of the more disreputable homeless. I’m 26 and it’s stressful being in close proximity with sex-offenders, rapists, and people who appear to be tweaking out on drugs, shaking and pacing and speaking to themselves.   These people still deserve help of course, I wouldn’t want them to have it even harder, the goal should be reacclimatization into society, but the spectrum of homeless people is very broad.   It’s not really helpful for me if I get panic attacks and flashbacks to hiding from my abusive father at night while people are pacing next to my bunk bed acting agitated and muttering.   It’s also just dangerous to quit drugs good turkey. Depending on what they use that could literally kill them. When I stayed at the shelter last someone died in a personal room for people in a special program from a heroin/fent related problem and they didn’t find him for multiple days until the stench of his decaying corpse in the heat warranted other homeless people complaining of the smell.   I shouldn’t have to explain how terrifying it is to trust your well being in a place like that.
